title: How to identify figurative language in a poem - Quora

response.answer_text: If it’s a poem, it’s probably using figurative language. Let’s look at the first stanza of Keats, To Autumn Season of mists and mellow fruitfulness, Close bosom-friend of the maturing sun; Conspiring with him how to load and bless With fruit the vines that round the thatch-eves run; To bend with apples the moss'd cottage-trees, And fill all fruit with ripeness to the core; To swell the gourd, and plump the hazel shells With a sweet kernel; to set budding more, And still more, later flowers for the bees, Until they think warm days will never cease, For summer has o'er-brimm'd their clammy cells. The first line is fairly literal, but in the second line we immediately have personification, which is extended throughout the poem. From here, everything is figurative, though it operates at additional levels and layers. Let’s look at something more recent, The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock, by TS Eliot. Let us go then, you and I,When the evening is spread out against the skyLike a patient etherized upon a table;Let us go, through certain half-deserted streets,The muttering retreatsOf restless nights in one-night cheap hotelsAnd sawdust restaurants with oyster-shells:Streets that follow like a tedious argumentOf insidious intentTo lead you to an overwhelming question ...Oh, do not ask, “What is it?”Let us go and make our visit. Again, the first line is (in poetic terms at least) fairly literal. The second line is a metaphor—the evening spread out. The third line is a simile, but a powerful and unexpected one. But, note, it is a simile of a metaphor. Now let’s look at Britain’s favourite poem, Sea Fever, by John Masefield. I must go down to the seas again, to the lonely sea and the sky,And all I ask is a tall ship and a star to steer her by;And the wheel’s kick and the wind’s song and the white sail’s shaking,And a grey mist on the sea’s face, and a grey dawn breaking. ‘lonely sea’ is a personification—or is it? You can also read it as a transference: it is not the sea that is lonely, but the author when he is at sea. The third line is a low-level personification, but this is raised to a higher level when we are actually shown the ‘sea’s face’.  In poetry, there are typically five or six forms of figurative language: Simile — at the most obvious level, and in a sense literal, ‘x is like y’.Metaphor — a metaphor is a simile without ‘like’. Instead of saying “it’s like a conspiracy”,. Keats says, in line 3 of To Autumn, ‘conspiring with him…’Personification — something inanimate is given human characteristics. Ruskin criticised this as ‘The Pathetic Fallacy’.[1] Ruskin was wrong.Symbol — something is used to represent something else without spelling it out. The ‘patient etherized’ in The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock is a symbol of Prufrock’s own life. We only find this out later.Conceit — a conceit is an extended piece of figurative language. The whole of To Autumn is a conceit, treating the season of Autumn (Fall, for Americans) as a person.Subject — in a poem which has distinct subject and theme, the subject itself is figurative. The subject of ‘To Autumn’ is (obviously) Autumn, but the theme is nostalgia. This is the sense in which most poetry — beyond the simplest form of narrative verse — is figurative. It may be talking about one thing, but what it means is something else. For example, in The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock, Prufrock’s indecision is itself a marker of the collapse of male confidence in modern life. It would be saying too much to call it a ‘symbol’.Footnotes[1] Of the pathetic fallacy by John Ruskin (1856)
Do you mean: how do you spot it? Or How do you point it out? You should probably define “identity” as used in your question.
